moves.1. d4 d5: The QP opening and the Classical reply.
moves.2. e4: An unusual variant, designed to open the game.
moves.3. Nc3: Developing and attacking the advanced Pawn.
moves.3... Nf6: Countering with a developing move that defends the Pawn.
moves.4... exf3: Unable to maintain the Pawn, Stock exchanges.
moves.5. Nxf3: The recapture puts Diemer's KN on its natural square.
moves.5... c6: Presumably, to prevent a move of P-Q5 by Diemer.
moves.6. Bc4: Down a pawn, Diemer plays aggressively. He has 3 pieces developed to just 1 for Stock.
moves.6... Nbd7: With QB3 occupied by a Pawn, Stock must play his QN to Q2 instead. His position is beginning to get cramped.
moves.7. Ng5: Diemer pressures the natural weakness, the KB2 square.
moves.7... Nd5: Blocking the diagonal of the Bishop.
moves.9. Nxf7: Stock resigns. If 9...KxN, 10 BxP ch would force his King into the open. 10 O-O ch or 10 Q-R5 ch or 10 Q-B3 ch would also be good options for Diemer.
